    I'm not sure what to put on this page yet. I suppose one day I will be confident enough to put up recordings of myself. Or maybe I will be able to play with a band. Meanwhile here's some rambling:

    My Music Journey

    Starting music in school

    In primary school, I learned to play the clarinet (Bb and bass) and saxophone (tenor). In secondary (middle) school I continued with band, playing the tenor and then the baritone saxophone.

    I didn't enjoy the music we played so I wasn't very motivated and stopped before JC (high school). I made only a few attempts to transcribe what I liked. I didn't really know that I could (and should) go my own way, beyond what I had been asked to do. I had also discovered some things, but I didn't know these were proper techniques until very much later.

    Saxophone as an Adult

    I began to miss the saxophone while I was at university. The local Yamaha music shop would hold regular sales, and one day there was a YAS-23, which I bought for about SGD 1.1k, in 2008 I believe. It's been with me ever since, and it still plays well. I did service it for SGD 400 in 2021.

    Upon graduation I took weekly lessons with a professional instructor. He corrected several mistakes and introduced new techniques, music theory, and resources. I stopped lessons after a year, as it came to a point where I wasn't making much progress, and it no longer felt worth the cost.

    Over the years the internet has grown in the availability of resources, both cheap and free. Teachers and solo recordings are all a click away. Progress is so much easier than before.

    Piano

    In med school I started toying with piano and keyboard. I had just discovered Clair de Lune, but I could barely play the first row of the first page. There were too many notes to sight read at once.

    Shortly after completing housemanship, I realized I had very little skill in general. For over 15 years I had diligently attended class and listened to instructors. But why couldn't I do anything? I was sick and tired of school and formal instruction.

    I decided to get serious and go my own way. I had devoured all of Nassim Taleb's books and was convinced the best way to learn piano was to dive headfirst into a piece. And, if I could enjoy playing rhythm games like "Guitar Hero", then I could have the same driving force.

    I chose to do "Clair de Lune" as it is a piece I can listen to over and over. Also, it sounds great even when played at a slow or inconsistent tempo. Not only is this very encouraging, it impresses people who don't play piano!
